title: Event ID 4662
lines: The increase in Event ID 4662 logs you're seeing is expectedâ€”itâ€™s tied to enabling the Directory Service Access audit policy as part of Advanced Audit Configuration.

These events arenâ€™t generated by Microsoft Defender for Identity (MDI) itself. They originate from Windows auditing when Active Directory objects are accessed. Once this policy is enabled, the system begins logging those operations in more detail, which naturally increases the volume of 4662 events.

MDI relies on this audit data to identify threats such as lateral movement, privilege escalation, and other advanced attack patterns. So, while the spike in logs may be noticeable, it reflects increased visibility and enhances the detection capabilities of Defender for Identity.

There arenâ€™t any configurable settings within Defender for Identity to reduce or control the volume of these events. The logging is driven by Windows audit policy once Directory Service Access is enabled.
Below are some helpful resources related to audit configuration and required Windows events for MDI:
Configure audit policies for Windows event logs - Microsoft Defender for Identity | Microsoft Learn
Event collection overview - Microsoft Defender for Identity | Microsoft Learn
4662(S, F) An operation was performed on an object. - Windows 10 | Microsoft Learn

title: Creating a DSA
lines: Create a Test Service Account
New-ADUser -Name "DSA_Test_Account" -SamAccountName "DSA_Test_Account" -AccountPassword (ConvertTo-SecureString "    " -AsPlainText -Force) -Enabled $true
Confirm account exists and enabled
Get-ADUser -Identity DSA_Test_Account | Select-Object Name, Enabled, SID
Validate Replication (Optional but Recommended)
repadmin /replsummary

title: "Understanding Defender for Identity Sensor Version and Health Status"
lines: ðŸ” Version Discrepancy: Portal vs. Programs and Features
Programs and Features
â€¢ Displays the version of the original MSI installer used to deploy the sensor.
â€¢ Does not update dynamically after automatic sensor upgrades.
Defender for Identity Portal
â€¢ Shows the live sensor version currently running and reporting to the cloud.
â€¢ Is the authoritative source for sensor version and update status.
âœ… If the portal shows the sensor as â€œUp to date,â€ the correct version is running â€” even if Programs and Features shows an older build.
âš ï¸ Sensor Health â‰  Sensor Version
A sensor can be:
â€¢ âœ… Up to date (latest version installed)
â€¢ âŒ Unhealthy (due to service failures, missing event logs, or connectivity issues)
Uninstalling and reinstalling the sensor will not resolve health issues unless the underlying cause is addressed.
ðŸ› ï¸ How to Resolve Unhealthy Sensor Status
1. Open the Defender for Identity portal.
2. Click into each affected sensor.
3. Review the Open Health Issues panel.
4. Follow the specific recommendations provided (e.g., restart services, adjust audit policies, fix connectivity).
â³ It may take several hours for the portal to reflect updated health status after remediation.
ðŸ” Optional: Align Displayed Version via Reinstall
If you want the version shown in Programs and Features to match the live sensor version:
Uninstall Steps
â€¢ Open Programs and Features
â€¢ Locate Azure Advanced Threat Protection Sensor
â€¢ Right-click and select Uninstall
Reinstall Steps
â€¢ Download the latest MSI from the Defender portal
â€¢ Run the installer on the same domain controller
Reuse the existing workspace key if the domain controller is still listed in the portal

title: HoneyToken
lines: Alerts are typically triggered when there are group membership changes involving the honeytoken or the group it resides in.
Some common causes include:
Â· Expected administrative activity
Â· Service accounts making automated changes
Â· Normal changes to the group that contains the honeytoken accoun
Best practices:
1. Review which account made the group membership change.
2. Confirm whether that account is a service account or an administrator performing expected activity.
3. Validate whether the change aligns with your organizationâ€™s intended configuration.
If the activity is legitimate, no further action is required. If not, then it may warrant deeper investigation on your side.

title: Testing
lines: testing. Lets do this. I'm just here to test edits. And another test. Another one bites the dust. Testing again. Testing after code changes.

title: False Positives - IP
lines: Example: Customer reports excessive false positive alerts in Microsoft Defender for Identity (MDI) due to IP address reassignment between devices. This behavior is impacting SecOps productivity by generating non-malicious alerts such as Pass-the-Ticket (PtT).
Recommended actions provided to customer:
1. Alert Tuning: Initiate tuning directly from the alert page in Defender XDR to adjust detection thresholds or suppress specific alert types.
2. Global Threshold Adjustments: Modify detection sensitivity across multiple alert types via Defender XDR settings.
3. IP Address Exclusions: Configure exclusions for known, low-risk IP ranges under Settings > Identities > Exclusions > Global Excluded Entities.
4. NNR Validation: Review Network Name Resolution (NNR) configuration to ensure IP-to-device mapping is functioning correctly. NNR failure can lead to misattributed activity and false PtT alerts.
Reference documentation shared:
â€¢ Adjust alert thresholds - Microsoft Defender for Identity | Microsoft Learn
â€¢ Detection exclusions in Microsoft Defender XDR - Microsoft Defender for Identity | Microsoft Learn
Network Name Resolution - Microsoft Defender for Identity | Microsoft Learn
kbText:
Example: Customer reports excessive false positive alerts in Microsoft Defender for Identity (MDI) due to IP address reassignment between devices. This behavior is impacting SecOps productivity by generating non-malicious alerts such as Pass-the-Ticket (PtT).
Recommended actions provided to customer:
	1. Alert Tuning: Initiate tuning directly from the alert page in Defender XDR to adjust detection thresholds or suppress specific alert types.
	2. Global Threshold Adjustments: Modify detection sensitivity across multiple alert types via Defender XDR settings.
	3. IP Address Exclusions: Configure exclusions for known, low-risk IP ranges under Settings > Identities > Exclusions > Global Excluded Entities.
	4. NNR Validation: Review Network Name Resolution (NNR) configuration to ensure IP-to-device mapping is functioning correctly. NNR failure can lead to misattributed activity and false PtT alerts.
Reference documentation shared:
	â€¢ Adjust alert thresholds - Microsoft Defender for Identity | Microsoft Learn 
	â€¢ Detection exclusions in Microsoft Defender XDR - Microsoft Defender for Identity | Microsoft Learn 
Network Name Resolution - Microsoft Defender for Identity | Microsoft Learn
